items.title: Olympic viewing guide Day 6: Get ready for a big Thursday
items.summary_auto: CBC Sports' daily Olympics newsletter previews a stacked Day 6 for Canada, including some strong gold-medal chances and the men's hockey opener.

items.title: Canadian skaters Gilles and Poirier find peace with an Olympic medal moment a lifetime in the making
items.summary_auto: It’s impossible to pinpoint where the Olympic journey started for Piper Gilles and Paul Poirier, Canada’s ice dance champions. It had a thousand starting points.

items.title: Boy, 13, who stabbed little brother handed 3-year sentence designed for youth with mental health issues
items.summary_auto: A 13-year-old Lethbridge, Alta., boy who tried to kill his seven-year-old brother by stabbing him was handed a three-year sentence on Wednesday, the maximum term allowed under the Youth Criminal Justice Act.

items.title: Mayor for Portapique tells Tumbler Ridge 'we understand' mass shooting devastation
items.summary_auto: Colchester County Mayor Christine Blair relates what her community experienced after the 2020 mass shooting that killed 22 people in Nova Scotia to Tuesday's mass shooting in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., advising that 'it will be surreal.' Blair says her community has experienced multiple suicides, and that instead of just an initial surge of support, trauma therapists should be made available in B.C. 'on a regular basis for years to come.'

items.title: Sask. mine that could make Canada world's biggest uranium exporter faces last hurdle
items.summary_auto: Hearings now underway in Saskatoon could decide the future of Canada’s biggest uranium mining project to date. Indigenous communities are now on board, but the proponent, NexGen, is still waiting on final say from the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission.

items.title: Text exchange that brought down Quebec Liberal leader was doctored, report finds
items.summary_auto: In a report commissioned by the party, a retired judge says the vote-buying scandal that ended Pablo Rodriguez’s stint as PLQ leader in late 2025 may have been sparked by manipulated evidence. The story that launched the scandal was published by the Journal de Montréal, which says the report commissioned by the PLQ is incomplete, that its author does not know the identity of their sources and that they stand by their reporting.

items.title: Trump meets with Netanyahu as Iran marks 47 years of Islamic rule
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Washington to discuss U.S. nuclear talks with Iran, but nothing definitive was decided. Meanwhile, thousands in Tehran marked the 47th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution.

items.title: Suspect's mother identified as 1 of 8 Tumbler Ridge, B.C., mass shooting victims
items.summary_auto: RCMP say nine people are dead in total, including the suspect, correcting their previous report of 10.

items.title: Unique Canadian fungus 'bank' saved by family foundation
items.summary_auto: A unique collection of microscopic fungi used for Canadian medical and biodiversity research has been saved from being shipped overseas.

items.title: Ukrainian Vladyslav Heraskevych is the most important athlete at the Olympics right now
items.summary_auto: The International Olympic Committee is not an organization that generally begs, but they are begging Ukrainian skeleton athlete Vladyslav Heraskevych not to compete in a customized helmet showing the faces of more than 20 Ukrainian athletes and coaches killed since Russian invaded Ukraine in 2022.

items.title: P.E.I. school officials didn’t mishandle complaints about substitute teacher, 3rd-party review finds
items.summary_auto: A review of sexual misconduct at P.E.I. schools sheds new light on what school officials knew about a substitute teacher who inappropriately touched students in the classroom — and when they knew it.

items.title: Vonn says she had 'successful' 3rd surgery on broken leg following alpine crash at Olympics
items.summary_auto: American skier Lindsey Vonn said Wednesday that she had a "successful" third surgery on her broken left leg following her downhill crash at the Olympics.

items.title: Dawson's Creek star James Van Der Beek dead at 48
items.summary_auto: James Van Der Beek, the actor best known for his role on 1990's TV show Dawson's Creek, has died. He was 48.

items.title: Community of Tumbler Ridge mourning victims of mass shooting
items.summary_auto: Residents of the small B.C. community of Tumbler Ridge are in shock after a mass shooting left 10 people dead Tuesday, including the suspect. The CBC's Nicole Oud is on scene in Tumbler Ridge, where she has been hearing from community members impacted by the violence.

items.title: Some Greenlandic Inuit say work on independence from Denmark will come amidst fight against U.S. threats
items.summary_auto: Over the decades, Greenland has gained more autonomy from the Kingdom of Denmark. But recent threats from U.S. President Donald Trump about taking over Greenland has brought the autonomous territory closer to the country that colonized it.

items.title: DNA breakthrough leads to charges in violent 1992 sexual assault in Alberta town
items.summary_auto: More than three decades after a woman was sexually assaulted at knifepoint inside her home in Two Hills, Alta., DNA evidence gathered from the scene has resulted in an arrest. Investigators say an accused was identified through a member of his family tree.

items.title: Deadly B.C. shooting is one of Canada's worst school shootings
items.summary_auto: Tuesday's mass shooting at Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in B.C. 's Peace region marked one of the worst school shootings in Canadian history, with nine people dead in total inside a school and a home, including a suspect.

items.title: FDA refuses Moderna's application for new mRNA flu vaccine, company says
items.summary_auto: Moderna received what’s called a “refusal-to-file” letter from the FDA that objected to how the company conducted a 40,000-person clinical trial comparing its new vaccine to one of the standard flu shots used today. Its a rare move by the FDA, which is under the control of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | On the ground in Tumbler Ridge, B.C.
items.summary_auto: RCMP on Wednesday provided an updated death toll for the mass shooting in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., saying that there are a total of nine dead, including the suspected shooter, not 10 as initially reported on Tuesday.

items.title: Royal Family among world leaders sending condolences after Tumbler Ridge mass shooting
items.summary_auto: The Royal Family are among the world leaders who have expressed condolences with Canadians in the wake of the mass shooting in Tumbler Ridge, B.C.

items.title: U.S. House votes against Trump's tariffs on Canada
items.summary_auto: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution against President Donald Trump's tariffs on Canadian goods, delivering a stinging rebuke to the administration for launching a trade war on its northern neighbour.

items.title: Norwegian biathlete expresses regret over public apology to ex-girlfriend after cheating confession
items.summary_auto: A day after a stunning confession on live television that he had cheated on his ex-girlfriend, Norwegian biathlete Sturla Holm Laegreid on Wednesday said he regrets going public with his private life at the Milan Cortina Winter Olympics.

items.title: Father, 2 children dead after murder-suicide in First Nation near Maniwaki, Que.
items.summary_auto: A man shot and killed his two children before taking his own life in Kitigan Zibi Anishinābeg early Wednesday, Quebec provincial police have confirmed.

items.title: Northern Alberta residents face barriers to blood donation despite urgent need
items.summary_auto: There is a need for blood after last month's winter storms cancelled drives across Canada, but donating blood isn't an option for residents in much of Fort McMurray and Grande Prairie, Alta.

items.title: FAA lifts closure of airspace over El Paso that had been enacted for 'special security reasons'
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration has called down a notice to halt all flights to and from El ​Paso International Airport in Texas ​for "special security reasons" just hours after it was issued.

items.title: 'I used to trust them': Family shattered after 6-month-old baby dies at Winnipeg Children's Hospital
items.summary_auto: A grieving father says he feels numb after taking his six-month-old son to a Winnipeg emergency department, believing he was in the right place to help his child. Ten hours later, his baby was taken into surgery and died.

items.title: Former kids in care sue N.S. government over 'segregation-like conditions'
items.summary_auto: Two people who were once children in the care of the province are suing Nova Scotia over conditions at Wood Street Centre, a provincially run facility for children in Truro.

items.title: For the first time in years, you can get a condo in Toronto for less than $400K. So what's the downside?
items.summary_auto: Recent data from the Toronto Regional Real Estate Board shows some Toronto condos are now selling for under $400,000, but experts warn if the current inventory goes fast the city could face another housing shortage.

items.title: This woman took a photo of a police drone. Then she got ticketed for distracted driving
items.summary_auto: On May 7, 2025, Kingston Police used a drone to catch distracted drivers in the act. Now, at least two of the 20 tickets issued that day have been withdrawn.

items.title: Northern Ontario town called out by First Nations over staff comment about 'colour'
items.summary_auto: A comment made by a municipal staff member in Marathon, Ont., has prompted calls for accountability from two nearby First Nations. While local First Nation leaders interpreted the remark as referring to skin colour, the town's mayor and senior administration say it was about political colours.

items.title: Stellantis keeping 650 staff hired for EV research in Canada, despite broader pullback
items.summary_auto: The global car behemoth might be offloading its stake in a massive electric vehicle battery plant in Canada — but it’s not giving up on electrification altogether.

items.title: Why some Canadian companies are turning their workers into owners instead of selling to the U.S.
items.summary_auto: A new type of employee ownership comes at a time when the country is facing a wave of baby boomer entrepreneurs nearing retirement and an increased focus on strengthening the national economy in the face of a trade war with the U.S.

items.title: Guelph, Ont., doctor en route to Gaza aide work says he was denied entry to Israel for carrying medical items
items.summary_auto: Dr. Hassan Kapasi of Guelph, Ont., says an Israeli border guard denied him entry while he was trying to get to Gaza after general medical equipment, including a stethoscope and Band-Aids, were found during a search of his bag.
